Climate change can be understood by summarizing the relationships between various factors contributing to it, extracting valuable insights and reasoning from pivotal events, and helping industry leaders make more informed decisions. We introduce the Science Daily Climate Change dataset (SciDCC), which contains over 11,000 climate change news articles scraped from the Science Daily website. This dataset can be used to extract prior knowledge for constructing climate change knowledge graphs.

News outlets have played a crucial role in raising awareness about climate change through their articles, leading to a growing understanding of its consequences. The increasing volume of news articles on climate change has made it challenging to extract valuable information from them. Algorithms that can extract and organize climate change information by condensing relevant knowledge from a large collection of news articles could be highly valuable in analyzing relationships between different factors responsible for climate change. This would help generate useful insights and reasoning about pivotal events, enabling industry leaders to make more informed policies related to climate change.

There has been a growing interest in generating high-quality knowledge graphs (KGs) for information extraction from raw text. Previous approaches to KG construction were either supervised or semi-supervised, which were expensive and time-consuming due to human supervision. Recently, neural models have enabled KG construction without human involvement. However, existing approaches use prior knowledge in the form of knowledge bases (KBs) to learn relationships between subject-object entity phrases, which is a major reason why constructing climate change KGs has been challenging.

To address this problem, we propose Neural NERE, an end-to-end Neural Named Entity Relationship Extraction model for constructing climate change knowledge graphs directly from raw text. We also introduce the SciDCC dataset, which contains over 11,000 news articles scraped from the Science Daily website. This dataset can be used to extract prior knowledge for constructing climate change knowledge graphs using Neural NERE.

The SciDCC dataset was created by web scraping news articles from the "Earth & Climate" and "Plant & Animals" topics in the environmental science section of the Science Daily website. The dataset contains 11,539 news articles, with an average title length of 9.32 words and an average summary length of 47.28 words.

Table 1 provides key statistics of the SciDCC dataset, including the number of news articles, news categories, and average and maximum lengths of titles, summaries, and bodies. Table 2 provides news category statistics, including the number of news articles in each category.
